texts.label: text
texts.orig: NOTE:  This post is out of date and is relevant only for GlusterFS 2.x.
texts.text: NOTE:  This post is out of date and is relevant only for GlusterFS 2.x.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: *High availability is certainly not a new concept, but if there's one thing that frustrates me with high availability VM setups, it's storage. If you don't mind going active-passive, you can set up
texts.text: *High availability is certainly not a new concept, but if there's one thing that frustrates me with high availability VM setups, it's storage. If you don't mind going active-passive, you can set up

texts.label: text
texts.orig: DRBD , toss your favorite filesystem on it, and you're all set.
texts.text: DRBD , toss your favorite filesystem on it, and you're all set.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If you want to go active-active, or if you want multiple nodes active at the same time, you need to use a clustered filesystem like  GFS2 ,  OCFS2  or  Lustre . These are certainly good options to consider but they're not trivial to implement. They usually rely on additional systems and scripts to provide reliable  fencing  and  STONITH  capabilities.
texts.text: If you want to go active-active, or if you want multiple nodes active at the same time, you need to use a clustered filesystem like  GFS2 ,  OCFS2  or  Lustre . These are certainly good options to consider but they're not trivial to implement. They usually rely on additional systems and scripts to provide reliable  fencing  and  STONITH  capabilities.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: What about the rest of us who want multiple active VM's with simple replicated storage that doesn't require any additional elaborate systems? This is where  GlusterFS  really shines. GlusterFS can ride on top of whichever filesystem you prefer, and that's a huge win for those who want a simple solution. However, that means that it has to use  fuse , and that will limit your performance.
texts.text: What about the rest of us who want multiple active VM's with simple replicated storage that doesn't require any additional elaborate systems? This is where  GlusterFS  really shines. GlusterFS can ride on top of whichever filesystem you prefer, and that's a huge win for those who want a simple solution. However, that means that it has to use  fuse , and that will limit your performance.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Let's get this thing started!
texts.text: Let's get this thing started!

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Consider a situation where you want to run a WordPress blog on two VM's with load balancers out front. You'll probably want to use GlusterFS's replicated volume mode (RAID 1-ish) so that the same files are on both nodes all of the time. To get started, build two small Slicehost slices or Rackspace Cloud Servers. I'll be using Fedora 13 in this example, but the instructions for other distributions should be very similar.
texts.text: Consider a situation where you want to run a WordPress blog on two VM's with load balancers out front. You'll probably want to use GlusterFS's replicated volume mode (RAID 1-ish) so that the same files are on both nodes all of the time. To get started, build two small Slicehost slices or Rackspace Cloud Servers. I'll be using Fedora 13 in this example, but the instructions for other distributions should be very similar.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: First things first — be sure to set a new root password and update all of the packages on the system. This should go without saying, but it's important to remember. We can clear out the default iptables ruleset since we will make a customized set later:
texts.text: First things first — be sure to set a new root password and update all of the packages on the system. This should go without saying, but it's important to remember. We can clear out the default iptables ruleset since we will make a customized set later:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# iptables -F
# /etc/init.d/iptables save
iptables: Saving firewall rules to /etc/sysconfig/iptables:        [  OK  ]
texts.text:
# iptables -F
# /etc/init.d/iptables save
iptables: Saving firewall rules to /etc/sysconfig/iptables:        [  OK  ]

texts.label: text
texts.orig: GlusterFS communicates over the network, so we will want to ensure that traffic only moves over the private network between the instances. We will need to add the private IP's and a special hostname for each instance to
texts.text: GlusterFS communicates over the network, so we will want to ensure that traffic only moves over the private network between the instances. We will need to add the private IP's and a special hostname for each instance to

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /etc/hosts
texts.text: /etc/hosts

texts.label: text
texts.orig: on both instances. I'll call mine
texts.text: on both instances. I'll call mine

texts.label: code
texts.orig: gluster1
texts.text: gluster1

texts.label: text
texts.orig: and
texts.text: and

texts.label: code
texts.orig: gluster2
texts.text: gluster2

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
10.xx.xx.xx gluster1
10.xx.xx.xx gluster2
texts.text:
10.xx.xx.xx gluster1
10.xx.xx.xx gluster2

texts.label: text
texts.orig: You're now ready to install the required packages on both instances:
texts.text: You're now ready to install the required packages on both instances:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: yum install glusterfs-client glusterfs-server glusterfs-common glusterfs-devel
texts.text: yum install glusterfs-client glusterfs-server glusterfs-common glusterfs-devel

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Make the directories for the GlusterFS volumes on each instance:
texts.text: Make the directories for the GlusterFS volumes on each instance:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: mkdir -p /export/store1
texts.text: mkdir -p /export/store1

texts.label: text
texts.orig: We're ready to make the configuration files for our storage volumes. Since we want the same files on each instance, we will use the
texts.text: We're ready to make the configuration files for our storage volumes. Since we want the same files on each instance, we will use the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: --raid 1
texts.text: --raid 1

texts.label: text
texts.orig: option.  This only needs to be run on the first node:
texts.text: option.  This only needs to be run on the first node:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# glusterfs-volgen --name store1 --raid 1 gluster1:/export/store1 gluster2:/export/store1
Generating server volfiles.. for server 'gluster2'
Generating server volfiles.. for server 'gluster1'
Generating client volfiles.. for transport 'tcp'
texts.text:
# glusterfs-volgen --name store1 --raid 1 gluster1:/export/store1 gluster2:/export/store1
Generating server volfiles.. for server 'gluster2'
Generating server volfiles.. for server 'gluster1'
Generating client volfiles.. for transport 'tcp'

texts.label: text
texts.orig: At this point, you're ready to start the GlusterFS servers on each instance:
texts.text: At this point, you're ready to start the GlusterFS servers on each instance:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: /etc/init.d/glusterfsd start
texts.text: /etc/init.d/glusterfsd start

texts.label: text
texts.orig: You can now mount the GlusterFS volume on both instances:
texts.text: You can now mount the GlusterFS volume on both instances:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
mkdir -p /mnt/glusterfs
glusterfs /mnt/glusterfs/
texts.text:
mkdir -p /mnt/glusterfs
glusterfs /mnt/glusterfs/

texts.label: text
texts.orig: You should now be able to see the new GlusterFS volume in both instances:
texts.text: You should now be able to see the new GlusterFS volume in both instances:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# df -h /mnt/glusterfs
Filesystem            Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/etc/glusterfs/glusterfs.vol
                      9.4G  831M  8.1G  10% /mnt/glusterfs
texts.text:
# df -h /mnt/glusterfs
Filesystem            Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/etc/glusterfs/glusterfs.vol
                      9.4G  831M  8.1G  10% /mnt/glusterfs

texts.label: text
texts.orig: As a test, you can create a file on your first instance and verify that your second instance can read the data:
texts.text: As a test, you can create a file on your first instance and verify that your second instance can read the data:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[root@gluster1 ~]# echo "We're testing GlusterFS" > /mnt/glusterfs/test.txt
.....
[root@gluster2 ~]# cat /mnt/glusterfs/test.txt
We're testing GlusterFS
texts.text:
[root@gluster1 ~]# echo "We're testing GlusterFS" > /mnt/glusterfs/test.txt
.....
[root@gluster2 ~]# cat /mnt/glusterfs/test.txt
We're testing GlusterFS

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If you remove that file on your second instance, it should disappear from your first instance as well.
texts.text: If you remove that file on your second instance, it should disappear from your first instance as well.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Obviously, this is a very simple and basic implementation of GlusterFS. You can increase performance by making dedicated VM's just for serving data and you can adjust the default performance options when you mount a GlusterFS volume. Limiting access to the GlusterFS servers is also a good idea.
texts.text: Obviously, this is a very simple and basic implementation of GlusterFS. You can increase performance by making dedicated VM's just for serving data and you can adjust the default performance options when you mount a GlusterFS volume. Limiting access to the GlusterFS servers is also a good idea.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If you want to read more, I'd recommend reading the  GlusterFS Technical FAQ  and the  GlusterFS User Guide .
texts.text: If you want to read more, I'd recommend reading the  GlusterFS Technical FAQ  and the  GlusterFS User Guide .

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Thank you for your e-mails!  I'll be expanding on this post later with some sample benchmarks and additional tips/tricks, so please stay tuned.
texts.text: Thank you for your e-mails!  I'll be expanding on this post later with some sample benchmarks and additional tips/tricks, so please stay tuned.
